summary: I am a researcher in palaeontology and ethnozoology. My current topic is evolution and extinction of island mammals, past and present and worldwide. I am particularly interested in insular biodiversity and the role of invasive species in the extinction of highly endemic island taxa. I am also investigating the skeletal morphology and histology of insular deer in relation to phylogeny and adaptation. One of my specialities is the interaction between humans and animals, including domestication, roles in art and mythology and practical use of animals.

treasury_media.title: Evolution and extinction of mammals on islands
treasury_media.description: My present research focuses on the evolution and extincton of insular mammals worldwide, past and present. One aspect is body size evolution: large mammals become smaller (dwarfism) and small mammals become larger (gigantism). The direction of body size evolution depends on ancestral size, topography and geography of the island, climate, the rest of the fauna, etc. The extinction of insular mammals nowadays is an ongoing problem. The causal factors are insufficiently known.

education.field_of_study: Biology, Physics, Chemistry, Mathematics, English, Dutch, German

organizations.name: Society of Vertebrate Paleontology, Society of Biogeography, Werkgroep Pleistocene Zoogdieren

projects.title: Island biodiversity and cultural evolution
projects.description:
The project investigates the impact of natural and anthropogenic changes to the insular environments and the importance of those changes to human culture. It is a multidisciplinary project, drawing on the expertise of an international team of scientists from different fields: Geosciences, Life Sciences and Humanities. The project is entitled Island biodiversity and cultural evolution.

In order to carry out the project, we selected islands from three different areas: the Eastern Mediterranean Sea (Crete, Karpathos and Cyprus), the Indian Ocean (Madagascar and Mauritius) and the western Pacific Ocean (Philippines: Luzon and Masbate). These areas have a different geologic, biogeographic and ethnographic background. Furthermore, these islands were colonized by humans during different periods in history (ranging from 800,000 years ago till the 17th century.)

projects.title: Of Mice and Mammoths
projects.description: I am involved in the project Of Mice and Mammoths (project leaders are Mark Lomolino, Dov Sax and Maria Rita Palombo). The project investigates the island rule and its workings, based on an extensive database which will for the first time include fossil insular mammals. Body masses of available fossil insular mammals are calculated or extrapolated and compared with data of the islands (degree of isolation, size of the island, latitude) and of the fauna (presence of competitors and predators and the nature thereof).

projects.title: Animals in Stone
projects.description: Animals in Stone, Indian fauna sculptured through time combines zoology and art history of the South Asian subcontinent. Indian mammals as they were sculptured in stone through the ages are compared with their living counterparts and their role in society and religion is discussed. The animals are sometimes rendered with great care and good observation, whereas others are no more than a vague reference to the animal in question. In some cases, the animals as prescribed in written text, appear to belong to a different species in the sculpture. A number of animals escaped depiction all together, either because they are very rare and seldom seen, or because they are not wanted. The overwhelming majority of animals depicted in stone sculpture is limited to the domestic animals. Only a minority of stone sculptures focusses on wild animals, some of which are nowadays extinct from the area.

profile_positions.description: I am specialised in the evolution, adaptation and extinction of island mammals past and present. My last project (Changing Invaders; NWO Veni) aims at quantifying skull shape and body mass changes rats that were introduced in Indonesia, the Philippines, New Zealand and almost all inhabited islands and atolls in the Pacific. I use this rat species and its hundreds of new homes as a multitude of experiments in a vast laboratory ('Nature's test tubes'). This will give more insight into the evolution of native island species in particular and macro-evolutionary processes in general.
profile_positions.title: Researcher

company.name: National and Kapodistrian University of Athens

profile_positions.company: National and Kapodistrian University of Athens
profile_positions.description: As research associate for the Museum of Palaeontology and Geology I collaborated in several project and wrote a number of scientific publications. Main projects were the digitalization of the museum's palaeontological collections, science communication to children aged 8-12 and developing the museum's new exhibition. Smaller, short-termed jobs included various museum-related jobs like catalogueing. Scientific publications focussed at primate morphology (Paradolichopithecus) and evolution of mammals on islands.
profile_positions.title: Research Associate

profile_positions.description: My research focusses on the evolution and extinction of mammals on islands worldwide. Information from extant or recently extinct insular mammals sometimes helps to understand processes of the past, but the opposite is true as well: information from the fossil record sometimes helps to understand ungoing processes.
profile_positions.title: Research Associate

profile_positions.description: For this project, I tracked parts of speech and treat them as if they were particles to predict their behaviour in a simulated environment.

profile_positions.description: Postdoctoral research on Animals in Stone. I wrote a monograph on the depiction of mammals in South Asian stone sculpture through time, including the role of mammals in South Asian societies and early domestication. See further http://users.uoa.gr/~geeraae/animalsinart.html

profile_positions.description: Director of a one-person translation (Adviesbureau Console) and (later) publishing company (Talen Instituut Console). Focus on travel and language guides and courses. Main products Sardinian and Sanskrit.
profile_positions.title: Director

profile_positions.description: Every summer, I joined the team of Aardwetenschappen (Geology) to excavate the cave Corbeddu in the valley Lanaittu in between the villages Oliena and Dorgali. This cave is filled with Late Pleistocene clayish sediments that are full of fossils of deer, pikas, mice and dormice plus a few remains of a little dog. Very rare, but extremely important, are human fossils. Three fragments of a paleolithic human (Homo sapiens) were discovered in this cave by the Dutch team. The Dutch team was locally assisted by staff from the Archaeological Surveys of Nuoro and Sassari, Italian scientists from Florence and Rome, and many invited specialists.
profile_positions.title: Excavator

profile_positions.description: My contribution: development of comprehensive linguistic rules for the grammar checker Dutch (MS Word) in close collaboration with the software developers.
profile_positions.title: Language Engineer
